childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1993-2005

You were born the year the World Trade Center was bombed for the first time. A truck full of explosives in a parking garage killed six people and injured over a thousand. It was supposed to collapse the towers. It didn't. The building stayed standing for another eight years, until you were eight years old. Then they finished the job.

Bill Clinton was inaugurated two months before you arrived, playing saxophone and promising a bridge to the twenty-first century. The Cold War had just ended. The Soviet Union was two years dead. America was supposed to be entering a new era of peace and prosperity. Your parents believed it. They had reason to—the '90s economy was booming, unemployment was low, the stock market was climbing. It felt like things were getting better.

Your childhood was the last of the analog era, but you caught the digital wave just in time to be fluent in both. You probably had a Nintendo or Sega Genesis before you had a home computer. You learned to type in computer class, not at home. The internet existed, but it was a thing that happened in the den, tied to a phone line, making sounds like a robot having a seizure. You waited three minutes for a single image to load.

You were four when Princess Diana died in a Paris tunnel—old enough to notice the adults were upset, too young to understand why they mourned someone they'd never met. Six when the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal broke, teaching you words you weren't supposed to know. Seven during Columbine, watching schools transform into places with lockdown drills. Eight when Y2K turned out to be nothing. These were the dinner table conversations of your childhood, the background noise of your formative years.

Your childhood was Nickelodeon and Pokémon and Beanie Babies your parents thought might fund your college education. It was Tamagotchis dying in your pocket because you forgot to feed them during class. It was Saturday morning cartoons and VHS tapes from Blockbuster. It was the last era when being unreachable was normal. Your parents couldn't text you. They had to trust you'd come home when the streetlights came on.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

You're a Millennial, born between 1981 and 1996 according to Pew Research, which became the official definition after years of boundary debates. Your generation is roughly 72 million people in the US, making it the largest cohort until Gen Z started catching up. You're in the later part of the range, which means you share some characteristics with older Gen Z while remaining distinctly Millennial.

The defining moment for Millennials was 9/11. You were eight. Third grade. Old enough to watch the towers fall on classroom televisions, young enough for that morning to fundamentally rewire your understanding of safety. You don't remember a pre-9/11 America with any clarity. Airport security, forever wars, color-coded terror alerts—that's just how things were for you.

Your generation graduated into the 2008 financial crisis or its long aftermath. You were fifteen when Lehman Brothers collapsed, which meant you watched your parents' retirement accounts evaporate, watched neighbors lose homes, learned early that the economy could break and nobody would fix it. By the time you entered the job market, the damage was done. Entry-level positions required five years of experience. Internships were unpaid. The gig economy was the only economy available.

Millennials are sandwiched between Gen X (who got theirs before everything collapsed) and Gen Z (who never expected to get anything). You're the generation that still believed the American Dream was possible, then watched it become a punchline. That disappointment—believing and then learning you shouldn't have—shapes everything about your worldview.

You've been blamed for killing everything from napkins to department stores to the diamond industry. You didn't kill anything—you couldn't afford it. You were too busy paying student loans and splitting rent four ways.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Jurassic Park terrified everyone with CGI dinosaurs that still hold up thirty years later and Schindler's List made everyone cry in black and white. Spielberg had a year. Groundhog Day came out, which would become shorthand for existential repetition for the next three decades. Sleepless in Seattle proved that Tom Hanks could make rom-coms as well as he made dramas.

Musically, 1993 was peak grunge transitioning into whatever came next. Whitney Houston's 'I Will Always Love You' refused to leave the charts. Nirvana was at its height—Kurt Cobain had a year to live. Dr. Dre had just dropped The Chronic and was changing hip-hop forever. Janet Jackson, Snoop Dogg, and Mariah Carey were all releasing defining work. The '90s had a sound, and 1993 was ground zero.

TV in 1993 gave us The X-Files, which spent nine seasons asking 'what if the government is lying about everything?' and never quite answering, though it turned out the answer was 'yes, obviously.' Late Night with Conan O'Brien premiered—Conan would host that show longer than you've held any job. NYPD Blue pushed the boundaries of network TV and everyone's parents complained about it.

Your childhood was peak '90s nostalgia material now. Power Rangers. Rugrats. Boy Meets World. Fresh Prince. Friends started when you were one and ended when you were eleven—you grew up with Ross and Rachel's drama playing in the background like ambient noise. Harry Potter arrived when you were four, and by the time you were a teenager, sorting yourself into Hogwarts houses was unironic identity formation.

The pop culture of your youth was pre-streaming, pre-binging, pre-algorithm. You watched what was on when it was on, or you missed it. This taught patience, which is a skill that gets less useful every year as instant gratification becomes standard. You couldn't demand entertainment on command. Entertainment showed up when it felt like it, and you were grateful.

By middle school, TRL was appointment viewing. Britney, Christina, *NSYNC, Backstreet Boys—the late '90s pop explosion was your soundtrack. You had an opinion about Britney versus Christina. You probably still do.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Mosaic launched—the first web browser with images, the thing that made the World Wide Web usable for normal people. Most people didn't know what a web browser was. Most people didn't need to. The internet in 1993 was 130 websites, total. It was a research tool for academics and a curiosity for hobbyists. By the time you were old enough to use it, it was eating the world.

Intel released the Pentium processor in 1993. This meant nothing to you at the time—you were learning to hold your head up—but it meant computers would get faster and cheaper throughout your childhood. Moore's Law was working overtime. Every year, technology improved. This felt like progress. It was, in ways that mattered and ways that wouldn't become clear for decades.

You were two when Windows 95 launched with a Rolling Stones commercial. Four when the first DVDs arrived. Five when Google was founded in a garage. Seven when the first camera phones appeared in Japan. Ten when Myspace launched. Twelve when Facebook opened to high schoolers. Fourteen when the iPhone changed everything. You didn't grow up with smartphones—you watched them conquer civilization in real-time.

This makes you a digital native who remembers the analog world clearly. You can use a touchscreen and explain what a rotary phone was. You know what dial-up sounds like. You've waited hours for a single song to download on Napster, only to find it was mislabeled. You've also gotten annoyed when a page takes more than two seconds to load. You contain both patience and impatience.

Your relationship with technology is complicated in ways younger generations don't quite understand. You remember when social media didn't exist, when phones were for calling, when being offline was the default state. You've watched screen time colonize every waking moment. You know it's probably bad for you. You can't stop. Nobody can.

You're fluent enough to troubleshoot your parents' tech problems and wise enough to be suspicious of every new platform. You watched Facebook go from 'fun way to connect with college friends' to 'democracy-eroding misinformation machine.' You've seen this movie before. You're not optimistic about how it ends.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

The World Trade Center bombing happened a month before you were born. Six people died, over a thousand injured, and America mostly forgot about it until September 2001, when you were eight years old. You watched the towers fall on live television, probably in a classroom. Your teacher didn't know what to say. Your parents picked you up early. The before and after of that morning divided your childhood.

Your pre-9/11 memories are fuzzy but real. You might remember a time when you could walk someone to an airport gate. When shoes didn't come off at security. When the word 'terrorism' wasn't daily vocabulary. That world ended before you turned nine.

You were four when Princess Diana died in a Paris tunnel. You probably didn't understand why adults were crying, but you learned that collective grief was something people did together, usually while watching television. You were five during the Lewinsky scandal, which taught you that adults lied about things and then lied about lying.

Columbine happened when you were six. School stopped feeling entirely safe. Lockdown drills became normal. The phrase 'active shooter' entered the vocabulary of childhood. You grew up preparing for violence in ways your parents never had to.

You were fifteen during the 2008 financial crisis. You watched your parents' retirement accounts evaporate on the evening news. You watched neighbors lose homes. You learned that the economy wasn't stable—it was a house of cards that rich people kept rebuilding with everyone else's money and calling it recovery.

By the time you graduated college around 2015, the world had changed again. Same-sex marriage was legal. Smartphones were universal. Social media had rewired how humans communicated. Donald Trump announced his presidential campaign. COVID hit when you were twenty-seven, early career, still establishing yourself. Your plans got postponed. Your sense of normal got permanently warped.

You've lived through more 'unprecedented' events than most generations see in a lifetime. The only constant has been the certainty that something else unprecedented is coming.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You graduated college around 2015, give or take. The economy had technically recovered from 2008, but 'recovered' meant stable enough for corporations to post record profits while wages stayed flat. Entry-level jobs still demanded three to five years of experience. Unpaid internships were still framed as opportunities rather than exploitation.

You're young enough to have missed the worst of the Great Recession's job market, but old enough to have absorbed its lessons through older siblings and cousins. You watched elder Millennials struggle. You learned that loyalty to employers is a sucker's game. You learned that 'stable career' is an oxymoron. You kept your resume updated and your options open because what choice did you have?

Your generation normalized the side hustle because one income stream wasn't enough. You've probably driven for Uber, sold things on Etsy, freelanced on Fiverr, or monetized a hobby just to make ends meet. The gig economy isn't liberation—it's what happens when traditional employment stops paying living wages. You became an entrepreneur by necessity, not choice.

You've worked in offices with ping pong tables and 'unlimited PTO' that nobody takes because the culture punishes rest. You've been told to 'bring your whole self to work' by companies that would fire you the moment quarterly earnings dipped. You've sat through mandatory fun and team-building exercises that felt more like hostage situations than morale boosters.

Remote work became normal because of COVID, which hit when you were in your late twenties. You proved you could do your job from anywhere. The reward was employers expecting you to be available everywhere, all the time, on your phone, during dinner, at 10 PM on a Sunday. Work-life balance became work-life blur.

You're in your early thirties now, which means you're old enough to have some career traction but young enough to feel like you're still waiting for things to stabilize. Spoiler: they won't. The stability your parents described isn't coming back. You've adapted to precarity because there was no other option.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the generation that grew up with dating apps as default. Tinder launched when you were twenty—early enough that swiping became natural, late enough that you remember meeting people in person. You've experienced both: the organic connection at a party, through friends, at school, and the algorithmic matching that reduces people to photos and bios. Both feel normal now.

You communicate primarily through text and DMs. Phone calls feel aggressive—why would you call without texting first to ask if calling is okay? Voicemails are relics. You can have entire relationships—flirtation, commitment, conflict, breakup—without ever hearing someone's voice. This is convenient and slightly dystopian, but it's just how things work.

Your generation delayed marriage and kids more than any before. Part of it is financial—weddings cost money you don't have, kids cost more, housing is impossible without inherited wealth. Part of it is cultural—the pressure to follow a traditional timeline has loosened, which is freeing but also disorienting. Part of it is practical—you want stability before adding dependents, but stability keeps taking longer to achieve.

You maintain friendships across distances through group chats and social media. Your best friend might live three time zones away. You might see your college roommate once a year but talk to them daily. Geography matters less than it used to, which is good for maintaining connections and bad for building community where you actually live.

You've been in at least one long-distance relationship, made possible by FaceTime and cheap flights. You've also experienced the weird loneliness of being hyperconnected online while feeling isolated in person. Connection and loneliness coexist in ways previous generations didn't have to navigate. You're still figuring out how to balance them.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were eight when the dot-com bubble burst—abstract at the time, something adults worried about while you worried about third grade. Fifteen during the 2008 financial crisis, which was not abstract at all. You watched adults lose jobs, lose homes, lose faith. Twenty-seven during the COVID-19 economic collapse. You've watched the economy implode three times before hitting thirty-five. This has given you a financial worldview best described as 'perpetually bracing for the next disaster.'

Your relationship with money is defined by scarcity that never quite lifts. You graduated with student loan debt that will follow you for decades. You watched housing prices climb 50%, 100%, 200% while your wages went up maybe 20%. The math doesn't work. It was never designed to work for you.

You save obsessively because you've seen how fast stability evaporates. You invest because you don't trust Social Security to exist when you're old, but you don't trust the stock market either, so you hedge, diversify, and hope for the best while expecting the worst. You're playing a rigged game because refusing to play means losing by default.

Boomers bought houses on a single income when houses cost twice their annual salary. Gen X got in before prices went parabolic. You're competing against investors who buy properties in cash and turn them into short-term rentals, driving up prices you already couldn't afford. Homeownership isn't a milestone anymore—it's a lottery you keep losing.

You've been lectured about avocado toast and subscription services by people who bought property for a year's salary and paid off mortgages before turning forty. The generational wealth gap is a chasm. You're on the wrong side of it. Your parents might own their home outright. You're calculating whether you'll ever own one at all.

Your generation is redefining financial success out of necessity. It's not a house in the suburbs—it's paying rent in a city where the jobs are while pretending you're not one emergency away from disaster. It's not retiring at sixty-five—it's hoping you can eventually slow down before your body gives out. The American Dream got repriced, and you couldn't afford the markup.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation confuses online engagement with real-world action more than you realize. You're great at hashtags, inconsistent at voter turnout. You can mobilize a million retweets for a cause and then not show up to the local election that would actually change policy. Digital activism feels like activism, but feelings aren't legislation.

You've been so thoroughly trained to cope with dysfunction that you sometimes forget to fight it. You normalize burnout as a badge of honor. You accept that healthcare comes from employers who can fire you at will, that education requires decades of debt, that housing is a luxury. You've adapted to a broken system so well that you've stopped demanding it be fixed.

You're so steeped in irony that sincerity feels risky. You can't just care about something—you have to care about it with self-aware distance, with acknowledgment of its problems, with protective layers of humor before anyone can mock your earnestness. This makes it hard to advocate for yourself without hedging. It makes asking for what you want feel naive.

Your generation's self-deprecation has become its own trap. Joking about being broke, anxious, exhausted—it's relatable, it gets engagement, it builds connection. But it also lets you avoid actually addressing the problems. Laughing about your suffering isn't the same as changing your circumstances. Sometimes the coping mechanism becomes the cage.

You're so used to being online that you underestimate how much offline life matters. The friends you text daily aren't the same as friends you see weekly. The communities you belong to on social media aren't the same as communities rooted in physical place and regular presence. You know this intellectually, but the pull of the screen is strong, and real-world connection takes effort the screen doesn't require.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2013-2023): You entered your twenties with Obama in the White House and left with a pandemic and a coup attempt. You started the decade as a fresh college graduate, cautiously optimistic because the economy was supposedly recovering. You ended it questioning whether anything was stable, because nothing was. This was supposed to be your 'figuring it out' decade. It was actually your 'surviving while pretending to figure it out' decade. You changed jobs, changed cities, maybe changed careers entirely. You learned that the life script your parents followed didn't apply to you.

Your 30s (2023-2033): You're in this decade now. COVID hit early and scrambled whatever plans you had. You're making more money than you did at twenty-five, but it still doesn't cover a down payment in any city with jobs. You're watching friends buy houses and have kids, and you're either doing the same or wondering if you ever will. This is the decade where you're supposed to 'have it together,' but having it together looks different than it did for your parents. You're building stability on shifting ground, and you know it could shift again at any moment.

Your 40s (2033-2043): Statistically, this will be your peak earning decade. You'll have more experience, more authority, more clarity about what you want. You'll also be sandwiched between aging parents who need care and kids (if you have them) who still need support. Your body will start sending strongly worded letters about the lifestyle choices of your twenties. This is the decade where you either double down on the path you're on or blow it up and start over. Both are valid. Neither is easy.

Your 50s (2043-2053): By this point, you'll have lived through at least four major economic crises, multiple 'once-in-a-generation' disasters that happened every few years, and complete transformations of how humans communicate, work, and relate. Retirement will be visible on the horizon but probably not reachable at sixty-five. You'll be mentoring people who don't understand why 2008 still haunts you. You'll catch yourself starting sentences with 'back in my day' and hating yourself for it.

Your 60s and beyond (2053+): Traditional retirement isn't guaranteed for your generation. It might be part-time work, phased retirement, or figuring out how to live on whatever Social Security still pays—if it still pays anything. Climate change will have reshaped geography and migration patterns. The technology landscape will be unrecognizable from what you grew up with. You'll tell younger people about dial-up internet, VHS tapes, and a time when phones couldn't take pictures. They'll look at you like you're describing the Middle Ages. You survived more change than any generation since the Greatest Generation. That counts for something, even if it doesn't pay the bills.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 4 million people born in 1993.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): You're more educated, more diverse, and significantly poorer adjusted for age. Gen X entered the workforce when the economy functioned, when degrees paid off predictably, when loyalty was rewarded. You entered after it broke. They got affordable college. You got crushing debt. They got pensions that actually existed. You got 401(k)s and hope.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is staggering. Boomers controlled about 21% of national wealth when they were your age. Millennials control about 7%. Boomers bought houses on single incomes for twice their annual salary. You can't afford one on two incomes when houses cost eight times the median wage. They retired with pensions and Social Security. You're hoping those programs survive long enough for you to qualify.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You share more than you differ. You both grew up with the internet. You both entered adulthood during crises. But you remember life before smartphones, however faintly. They don't. You had a childhood largely offline. They were posting on social media before they could read. You're slightly more optimistic, or at least you remember a time when optimism made sense. That memory makes disappointment sharper.

Your life expectancy is around 78-82 years, which is actually lower than it should be. Your generation has higher rates of 'deaths of despair'—suicide, overdose, alcohol-related death—than previous generations at the same age. Mental health outcomes are worse. Anxiety and depression are more common. The world you inherited is harder, and it shows in the numbers.

But you're also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic injustice than any generation before. You've pushed for equity, destigmatized mental health, and refused to accept what previous generations considered inevitable. The world is worse in some ways and better in others, and you're part of the reason for both.

year_events: World Trade Center bombed for the first time
Jurassic Park broke box office records with CGI dinosaurs
